From the Convento del Carmine, reported by Alessi as one of several find in the years preceding 1833
Photo Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonino Salinas
Partially reopened following extensive restoration work. Comprehensive collection of archaeological material, predominantly from the West of the island, with an important Etruscan collection.
Centre of Palermo, Piazza Olivella 24, 90100 - Palermo

Dis Manibus sacrum Lurius Zosimus vixit annis VII Luria Melanthin suo filio fecit

1D·M·S
2LURIUS·ZOSIMUS
3VIX·ANNIS·VII
4LURIA·MELANTHI·
5·N·SUO·FILIO·FECIT·

DISMANIBUSSACRUMLURIUSZOSIMUSVIXITANNISVIILURIAMELANTHINSUOFILIOFECIT

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text from photograph;
  • Line.4: Alessi reported the text as intact and read MELANTHI· ; the text seems to have suffered damaged to the right margin since discovery
  • Line.4-5: Mommsen suggested 'potius Melanth(e) in suo, quam Melanthin(a) suo'.

English translation

Jonathan Prag

Sacred to the shades of the underworld. Lurius Zosimus lived for 7 years. Luria Melanthin made it for her son.

commentary

The reading Melanthin, based on Alessi's text is acceptable as it is: this is the Latin transliteration of the Greek name Μελάνθιν, a "shortened" diminutive of Μελανθώ (via Μελάνθιον); this type of "shortening" in -ιον and -ιος endings (the exact nature of which, whether phonetic or morphological, is debated) occurs very frequently in inscriptions and papyri of the Roman period. The form Μελάνθιν is attested once in a third-century AD Macedonian inscription (IG 10.2,1 204), whereas LGPN has 4 attestations of Μελανθώ dating to the Hellenistic period.

Dis Manibus sacrum Lurius Zosimus vixit annis VII Luria Melanthin suo filio fecit
Text from photograph Alessi reported the text as intact and read MELANTHI· ; the text seems to have suffered damaged to the right margin since discovery Mommsen suggested 'potius Melanth(e) in suo, quam Melanthin(a) suo'.

Sacred to the shades of the underworld. Lurius Zosimus lived for 7 years. Luria Melanthin made it for her son.

The reading Melanthin, based on Alessi's text is acceptable as it is: this is the Latin transliteration of the Greek name Μελάνθιν, a "shortened" diminutive of Μελανθώ (via Μελάνθιον); this type of "shortening" in -ιον and -ιος endings (the exact nature of which, whether phonetic or morphological, is debated) occurs very frequently in inscriptions and papyri of the Roman period. The form Μελάνθιν is attested once in a third-century AD Macedonian inscription (IG 10.2,1 204), whereas LGPN has 4 attestations of Μελανθώ dating to the Hellenistic period.
